4.00.text:
At Ramps on the Moon, we always say
that we want to change the world.

24.56.text:
My name is Michele Taylor and I work as
Director for Change for Ramps on the Moon.

28.92.text:
And I’m not affiliated or aligned
with any of the organisations

33.64.text:
because I am self employed.
I’m a freelancer.

35.68.text: So I have a position of independence.

38.44.text:
Ramps on the Moon is a consortium
of seven organisations.

43.88.text:
Six venue based theatre companies
and Graeae Theatre Company.

49.24.text:
It was set up in order to
increase the number

54.24.text:
of Deaf and disabled people
in the world of theatre.

58.24.text: My name is Jenny Sealey - Jenny.

62.40.text:
I’m the Artistic Director of
Graeae Theatre Company.

65.48.text:
Graeae for many, many
years has been pushing

68.60.text:
and challenging the
mainstream theatre world

71.64.text:
saying, please can we have access for
the performers on your stages.

84.96.text:
I’m Chief Executive of the
New Wolsey Theatre in Ipswich.

87.64.text:
We are one of the partners in the
Ramps on the Moon consortium

92.00.text:
and the leading partner on the
organisational side of it.

95.68.text: Before Ramps on the Moon was created

98.60.text:
there was some absolutely
fantastic and excellent work

101.32.text:
being done by companies that were
disabled led like Graeae or Deafintely,

106.88.text:
and they were really quite
extraordinary -

109.04.text:
the productions and the work
they were achieving,

111.48.text:
in training people and getting the
work out for a bigger audience.

115.32.text:
What wasn’t happening
was in the mainstream.

118.24.text:
The mainstream really
needed to have a look

121.24.text:
at the way they were
running their organisations

126.72.text:
of what their attitude was -
all the way through.

129.64.text: One of the things I have noticed

131.76.text:
is that I’ve seen individuals understand
issues around inclusion,

137.32.text:
what I haven’t seen so often,
is organisations change.

142.44.text:
So the thinking behind having a consortium of,
if you like, mainstream theatres

149.28.text:
is that we want to make sure that Deaf
and disabled people's involvement

157.72.text:
So backstage, as audience, as artists,
as directors, as employees in theatres.

165.08.text:
This is about Deaf and disabled actors
being able to play any role.

169.24.text:
I’m Stuart Rogers, Executive Director
of Birmingham Repertory Theatre.

173.16.text:
We’re one of the partners of the
Ramps on the Moon initiative.

177.56.text:
The Rep was lucky enough to be
the first of the partner theatres

181.20.text:
to put on a
Ramps on the Moon production.

183.24.text:
And what we try to do is when
we’re selling the show,

185.96.text:
we’re selling it as a perfectly
normal show at Birmingham Rep.

189.04.text:
So it’s not being sold as a show
that is with disabled people

194.96.text:
It’s just a show -
it’s one of our shows.

197.40.text:
As ‘Tommy’, the current show
touring, is being sold now.

203.96.text:
<i>[Music from The Who's Tommy -
Pinball Wizard]</i>

221.40.text:
So what we were really pleased
about is that audiences came,

224.80.text:
were exposed to a whole
range of people

226.80.text:
they’ve never seen on stage
before with various disabilities.

230.32.text:
A whole range of access tools
combined in the production,

234.40.text:
so not added on, they were
actually integral to the production.

237.76.text:
And audiences loved it.
I mean they actually adored it.

240.32.text:
Whether they were disabled or non
disabled doesn’t make any difference.

243.64.text:
They actually liked the fresh approach
and the feel to the production.

249.00.text:
The single biggest lesson we’ve
passed on our colleagues,

253.24.text:
who are now producing the shows,
is planning.

256.60.text:
That actually you have to
allow for so much time.

259.48.text: All of that has to be expanded

261.40.text:
because you don’t quite know
what you’re going to meet

263.92.text:
and because of having to deal with
people with very different needs,

267.40.text:
very different access needs, and
making sure its working for everybody.

271.92.text:
You just have to think about,
‘what is the physical access?’

275.40.text:
The ramps, the interpreters,
the audio describers.

278.88.text: Just putting those things in place.

281.00.text:
But at the end of the day,
how you rehearse

284.40.text:
is the same as you would
rehearse with any cast.

287.36.text:
You are rehearsing a group of
actors to create the best show.

292.84.text:
One of the things we do in the world
of theatre is we take risks all the time.

297.84.text:
I’ve been saying to partner
organisations

300.56.text:
and to other people that I talk to
about Ramps on the Moon;

304.12.text:
you can’t wait until you're confident
about getting it right, before you do it.

309.92.text: You just have to do it.

312.40.text:
We’ve got to start taking risks around
inclusion of Deaf and disabled people.

317.04.text:
And be prepared to get it wrong,
get feedback, and learn.

321.32.text:
Being part of the Ramps on the Moon
initiative has had a big impact on us

325.08.text:
in terms of the range of work
we’re now doing.

327.56.text:
Within our production process schedule
where we have production planning meetings,

332.12.text:
which normally involve the designer,
the sound designer, the lighting designer

337.16.text: we have built in to that process

339.48.text:
a discussion about the access
needs of every production.

342.16.text:
That doesn’t feel like a massive thing
but it is a massive thing

344.52.text:
because it is suddenly up there
with the same status

347.28.text:
as the way it looks
and the way it feels.

349.92.text:
For me it’s been
very, very interesting

352.28.text:
to see how the theatres are
developing and understanding

357.08.text:
and really immersing themselves
in everything that is about access

362.12.text:
and embracing Deaf
and disabled artists.

364.60.text:
They all have an Agent for Change
who is pushing the agenda,

369.92.text:
really outreaching and finding
those audiences.

373.72.text:
All of them have had Deaf and
disability awareness training.

377.76.text:
So they’re opening their eyes.
They’re just hungry and really grabbing it.

383.52.text:
I think we will see within time, a lot more
younger Deaf and disabled people

388.44.text:
feeling that going into the
theatre profession,

391.60.text: to the arts and working in culture,

395.44.text: That they will be able to have careers.

397.52.text:
And that will a big impact on the wealth
of talent and diversity.

402.08.text: There will be more training opportunities,

403.76.text:
there will be more work
opportunities.

405.40.text: I think this is just the tip of the iceberg.

406.96.text:
I think it is going to become even
bigger and more widespread.
